half.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: exactly or about 50% (½) of an amount, time, distance, number etc
half.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: Only half the guests had arrived by seven o’clock.
If you look at our members, at least half are women.
It’s about half a mile down the road.
She drank half a bottle of wine.
You can’t just waltz in a half hour late.
It’s about a half mile down the road.
a half day excursion to the island
He demanded a half share of the money.
It’s only half the size of a normal violin.
They offered to pay half the cost of repairs.
Over half of the children live in one-parent families.
half.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: She seems to be asleep half the time.
Getting covered in mud is half the fun.
We missed half of what he said because someone was talking.
half.translation[0].note_box[0].items[0]: You say one and a half, two and a half etc
She is two and a half
half.translation[0].note_box[0].items[1]: The phrases one and a half, two and a half etc are followed by a plural noun
We were there for one and a half days
We were there for one and a half day
half.translation[0].note_box[0].items[2]: You can use half (of) with a plural noun and a plural verb
half.translation[0].note_box[0].items[3]: You can use half (of) with an uncountable noun and a singular verb
half.translation[0].note_box[0].items[4]: I’ve only read half the story
I’ve only read the half story
half.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: one of two equal parts of something
half.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: My son’s three and a half now.
an hour and a half later
two and a half thousand people
in the first half of the 19th century
He kept the other half of the cake for himself.
A veil covered the lower half of her face.
the southern half of the country
She tore the piece of paper in half.
a plan to cut European forces by half
half.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: one of the two parts into which a sports event is divided
half.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: France played very well in the first half.
half.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: a player who plays in the middle part of the field in sports like football, rugby etc
half.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: a half of a pint of beer
half.translation[1].definitions[3].examp: Can I have a half of lager, please?
half.translation[1].definitions[4].defin: a child’s ticket, for example on a bus or train, that is cheaper than an adult’s ticket
half.translation[1].definitions[4].examp: One and a half to Waterloo, please.
half.translation[1].note_box[0].sections: He tore the paper in half.
The company has reduced the number of staff by half.
The number of passengers using the service has increased by half.
He graduated in the top half of his law school class.
The upper half of the door contained a stained glass window.
The northern half of the city is generally poorer.
Profits doubled in the first half of the year.
Half the patients were given the drug and the other half were given a sugar pill.
He struggled with ill health in the latter half of his life.
‘How old is she?’ ‘Five and a half.’
half.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: He was half in the water and half out.
She was standing there half dressed, putting on her make-up.
The door was only half closed.
The jug was still half full.
I was half expecting her to say ‘no’.
I half hoped that they wouldn’t come.
half.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: if something is half one thing and half something else, it is a combination of those two things
half.translation[2].definitions[2].defin: used to emphasize something bad, to say that it is almost an extremely bad thing
half.translation[2].definitions[2].examp: He was half dead with exhaustion.
I had been driven half out of my mind with worry.
half.translation[2].definitions[3].defin: half the size, amount etc of something else
half.translation[2].definitions[3].examp: The new machine has all the same functions, but is only half as large.
half.translation[2].definitions[4].defin: larger by an amount that is equal to half the original size
half.translation[2].definitions[4].examp: A flat in London costs almost half as much again as a flat in Glasgow.
